title: 108_hr4889
content: The Act titled "Haiti Economic Recovery Opportunity Act of 2004" provides trade benefits to Haiti under a special rule inserted after section 213 of the Caribbean Basin Economic Recovery Act. Beginning on October 1, 2003, apparel articles wholly assembled or knit-to-shape in Haiti can enter the US duty-free for 7 one-year periods, subject to certain conditions. Beginning on October 1, 2003, Haiti is eligible to import apparel articles duty-free for 7 one-year periods, with the quantity increasing annually based on a percentage of previous imports. The text chunk discusses the eligibility requirements for Haiti to receive preferential treatment, including the establishment of a market-based economy, the rule of law, political pluralism, and the elimination of barriers to trade and investment. The curr_chunk discusses measures to promote trade and investment, protect intellectual property, resolve disputes, reduce poverty, improve healthcare and education, develop private enterprise, build infrastructure, combat corruption, and bribery. The curr_chunk focuses on combating corruption, protecting worker rights, ensuring national security interests, and preventing gross violations. The curr_chunk highlights the conditions Haiti must meet to receive preferential treatment, including adopting an effective visa system and domestic laws to prevent unlawful transshipment and counterfeit documents. Haiti must enact legislation and regulations allowing access for Customs and Border Protection teams to investigate transshipment allegations. Haiti also agrees to report exports and imports of specified articles to the US and cooperate to prevent circumvention. Haiti agrees to maintain production and export records for specified articles for at least 2 years and report documentation on the country of origin when requested by Customs and Border Protection to prevent circumvention. The term 'circumvention' refers to actions involving false information to violate customs, country of origin labeling, or trade laws to avoid tariffs or obtain preferential treatment. The term 'transshipment' is also defined. The term 'transshipment' is defined as per section 213(b)(2)(D)(iii). The effective date for the amendment is October 1, 2003, applying to goods entered or withdrawn from warehouse for consumption. Retroactive application is allowed for entries made between October 1, 2003, and the enactment date upon proper request filed within 90 days. Entries made before the enactment of the Act will be adjusted as if the new amendment applied to them.
